citation.article-title: Characterization of Lawsonia intracellularis gen. nov., sp. nov., the obligately intracellular bacterium of porcine proliferative enteropathy.

p.s: Description of Lawsonia gen. nov.
Lawsonia (Law.son.ia. L.n. Lawsonia, in honor of G. H. K. Lawson, the discoverer of the bacterium)
Non-spore-forming curved rods (ca. 1.5 by 0.35 Î¼m).
Gram-negative cells retain carbol-fushsin when they are stained by the modified Ziehl-Neelsen method.
Nonflagellated.
Nonpigmented.
Sections reveal the cell wall profile of a gram-negative bacterium and the protoplasmic structure of a procaryote.
Cells characteristically replicate within the cytoplasm, are not enclosed by membrane-bound vacuoles, and occur in epithelial cells in the ilea of pigs.
Best revealed in histological sections by silver-staining techniques.
Intracellular organisms exhibit acidfast staining in smears of intestinal epithelium and enterocytes with the modified Ziehl-Neelsen acid-fast stain.
Multiplies by septum formation.
Does not reduce sulfate.
Cannot be cultivated in cell-free media.
Grows intracellularly in enterocytes and requires a microaerophilic atmosphere for growth.
The sequence of 16s rDNA shows that these bacteria are members of the delta subdivision of the Proteohacteria.
Distinct from certain Desulfovibrio spp. in electrophorctic protein profiles, DNA probe reactions, and monoclonal antibody reactions.
Isolated from the intestinal epithelial cells of pigs with proliferative enteropathies.
Pathogenic for pigs with an intestinal flora.
The type strain is strain NCTC 12656 (= 1482/89).
Designation of the type strain.

The type strain is 1482/89, which was cocultured in a rat enterocyte cell line that was infected with a suspension of bacteria obtained from a pig with proliferative enteropathy and maintained in a rat enterocyte cell culture.
This strain reproduces effectively in rat enterocytes without noticeable cytopathic effects or threat to culture survival.
Strain 1482/89T has been deposited in the National Collection of Type Cultures, Colindale, London, United Kingdom, as strain NCTC 12656T.
The bacterium growing in a cell culture conforms to the genus and species description given above.
